ADU1.text: "What Should We Do With Our Brains? is a book that

ADU2.text: "Malabou's project bears a certain resemblance to Kant's critical project."

ADU3.text: "The conditions of the question 'What Should We Do?' have changed since Kant's time."

ADU4.text: "The question of freedom has been inverted since Kant."

ADU5.text: "Malabou links the question of freedom with the structure of the brain."

ADU6.text: "Malabou's title question can be understood as 'How should we use neuroscience?'"

ADU7.text: "Neuroscience has a unique position: it is a human science

ADU8.text: "Neuroscience claims to give us a scientific explanation of something that eludes science

ADU9.text: "Neuroscience forms the current scientific conception of what Noam Chomsky might call 'human nature'."

ADU10.text: "Malabou analyzes three 'fields of action' in the brain where plasticity plays a fundamental role."

ADU11.text: "There is developmental plasticity in the brain."

ADU12.text: "There is modulational plasticity in the brain."

ADU13.text: "There is reparative plasticity in the brain."

ADU14.text: "Malabou provides a conceptual analysis of the notion of plasticity."

ADU15.text: "The concept of plasticity contains within itself two contradictory extremes."

ADU16.text: "The question for Malabou is whether brain plasticity is a model of freedom."

ADU17.text: "Malabou argues that the potential for both freedom and biological justification of the manner in which the brain is molded is inherent in the notion of brain plasticity."

ADU18.text: "Malabou's main point of reference is the 1999 book by Luc Boltanski and Eve Chiapello."

ADU19.text: "Malabou points out that employment has become synonymous with being adaptable and flexible."

ADU20.text: "Malabou draws a parallel between the neuronal and the social."

ADU21.text: "The shift in our global capitalist economy has generated a conceptual shift that has altered our view of the way the brain functions."

ADU26.text: "The plasticity of the brain can move in one of two directions."

ADU27.text: "The plasticity of the brain can constitute the biological justification of a type of economic

ADU28.text: "The plasticity of the brain can allow us to think a multiplicity of interactions in which the participants exercise transformative effects on one another."

ADU29.text: "Malabou's strategy is to interrogate the transition from the neuronal to the mental."

ADU30.text: "Malabou challenges the idea that there is a continuity from the biological to the cultural."

ADU31.text: "The transition from the neuronal to the mental is a philosophical or epistemological position."

ADU32.text: "Malabou turns to the work of Antonio Damasio."

ADU34.text: "The proto-self indicates the way the brain represents the organism to itself."

ADU35.text: "Consciousness emerges from the proto-self in a progressive manner."

ADU37.text: "Not all neuronal patterns become images or signs."

ADU38.text: "Malabou suggests that the transition from the neuronal to the mental proceeds by intermediate plasticity."

ADU39.text: "This intermediate plasticity is situated between the proto-self and the conscious self."

ADU40.text: "Malabou proposes a Hegelian reading of the neurosciences."

ADU41.text: "Malabou's ultimate position is closer to Foucault and Deleuze."

ADU42.text: "Malabou's characterization of the neuronal self is Foucauldian in tone."

ADU43.text: "Malabou concludes her book in a Foucauldian vein."

ADU44.text: "Malabou's answer to the question 'What should we do with our brain?' is to understand plasticity as the production of the new."

ADU45.text: "Malabou's problem with the neurological revolution is that it has revolutionized nothing for us."

ADU46.text: "The only real view of progress opened by the neurosciences is that of an improvement in the quality of life."

ADU47.text: "Malabou calls for an 'awakening of a consciousness of the brain'."

ADU48.text: "The production and constitution of the new is nothing other than the movement of the problem that seems to animate this entire book - namely
